vectorData.altText:
Movement between two or more bones occurs at joints. The starting point for these descriptions is taken to be the anatomical position.
Linear motion occurs when bones translate     relative to each other, a movement that is often described as gliding; e.g. gliding occurs between the carpal bones of our wrists. 
Angular motion occurs when the angle between two bones changes. 
Flexion and extension are antagonistic      movements that occur in the sagittal plane, therefore moving a body part anteriorly or posteriorly. Flexion decreases the angle between articulating elements, extension increases the angle between articulating elements     . There is one exception to this definition     . 
Abduction and adduction     are antagonistic movements that occur in the coronal plane, relative to the midline of the body. Abduction is a movement away from the midline, adduction is a movement toward the midline. Abduction and adduction occur at the shoulder and hip, for example, when we do jumping jacks          . 
Rotation occurs around the long axis of a bone or structure. 
Medial and lateral rotation occur in the limbs when we rotate them inward, toward the midline and outward, away from the midline, respectively. Medial and lateral rotation occur at the shoulder and hip, for example     .
Left / right rotation occurs with rotation of the vertebral column around its long axis     .
Back on your feet and give me 20!
parallel movement; movement without rotation or a change in angle between the articulating elements

abduction, L, ab = from; duco = “I lead”
adduction, L, ad = to; duco = “I lead”

Stand up and perform all the movements illustrated, starting from the anatomical position. Notice that flexion of the elbow brings the forearm forward, while flexion of the knee brings the leg backward.
Therefore, in general, the definition of flexion and extension have nothing to do with the direction of the movement, and everything to do with the change in angle between the articulating elements.

This definition does not work for the shoulder.
Therefore, by convention, flexion of the shoulder is movement of the arm forward and extension of the shoulder is movement of the arm backwards.
In the case of the fingers, the “midline” is not the midline of the body, but the midline of the hand, running through the middle finger.

Perform these movements as illustrated, and be sure you understand them. 
Notice that medial and lateral rotation of the hip occurs around the long axis of the femur, and that medial and lateral rotation of the shoulder occurs around the long axis of the humerus.
